title: Chinese stocks put on ice in attempt to stem market crash
text:

Wed, Jul 8, 2015, 13:33 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 57 mins Chinese stocks put on ice in attempt to stem market crash By Peter Spence | Telegraph – 24 minutes ago +0.640 
More than three-quarters of Chinese shares were frozen on Wednesday 
Trading on more than three-quarters of China’s stock market was motionless for much of Wednesday’s session, as authorities took further steps to stem a massive equities sell-off. 
Hundreds of companies listed on the Shanghai Composite halted trading in their stock, while the share prices of others fell by the maximum daily limit of 10pc, preventing investors from selling around 22pc of stocks on the index. 
Traders have scrambled to get out of Chinese equities in recent weeks, leading the country’s largest index to lose close to a third of its value in less than a month. Kit Juckes, of Societe Generale (Paris: FR0000130809 - news ) , said: “The Chinese authorities' attempts to stabilise the equity market are not working.” 
The Shanghai Composite fell by a further 5.9pc on Wednesday, as stock trading halts and price movement limits prevented investors from pushing the index even lower. 
“The symbiotic relationship between the Chinese economy and global commodity markets is once again highlighted as iron ore, copper, gold and oil prices all fell,” Mr Juckes said. 
As the market has gained “bear” status, the Chinese government has attempted to reverse the crash in stocks. Jason Ambrose, of Vanda Research, said: “Policymakers have kitchen-sinked it trying to support markets." 
• Why Chinese stocks are in turmoil • Jumping back into volatile China is only for the brave 
The last few days have seen central bank rate cuts, reduced trading fees, relaxed margin-lending rules, and stock purchases by the country’s sovereign wealth fund. China’s leaders “are beginning to worry about the potential for social unrest”, said Mr Ambrose. The country’s stock market has shrunk by around £2.1 trillion in the last month. 
The Chinese government has attempted to reverse the crash in stocks 
Analysts fear that halting trading will do little to improve matters, and may in fact dent confidence in the stock market further. 
Companies are able to apply to the stock exchange to have trading in their stocks suspended. Many of them said that they had an “important project in preparation”. 
• The really worrying financial crisis is happening in China, not Greece • ‘Rats leaving a sinking ship’ as China’s equity bubble implodes 
Mr Ambrose continued: “The issue at the heart of it, and more generally the biggest weakness of the central planning model is that it’s easy to get large state-run bodies to spend more on railroads or buy up stocks, but it’s a lot harder to convince a billion people to collectively act in a counter-cyclical way.” 
The market is now “experiencing a complete breakdown of confidence in the Beijing Put”, he said, a rally in stock markets that has been driven by government policy. “So if you lose confidence in the effectiveness of those policies, you lose the basis for the entire rally.”
